CLINTON_199_2.input:
CLINTON: "which may prove to be an intelligence benefit
we've got to do everything we can to vacuum up intelligence from Europe, from the Middle East
That means we've got to work more closely with our allies, and that's something that Donald has been very dismissive of
We're working with NATO, the longest military alliance in the history of the world, to really turn our attention to terrorism
We're working with our friends in the Middle East, many of which, as you know, are Muslim majority nations
Donald has consistently insulted Muslims abroad, Muslims at home, when we need to be cooperating with Muslim nations and with the American Muslim community
They're on the front lines
They can provide information to us that we might not get anywhere else
They need to have close working cooperation with law enforcement in these communities, not be alienated and pushed away as some of Donald's rhetoric, unfortunately, has led to"

cqs.cq: If Clinton is going to make such a big deal about how she is going to work with Muslims, then why is she going to deport them?
Is it fair to say that Trump is not a racist?
Why would a Muslim not be able to be a good police officer?
If you see Islam as a religion of peace, then why do you think we need to be working with Muslim nations?

CLINTON_1_2.input:
CLINTON: "If you help create the profits , you should be able to share in them , not just the executives at the top
I want us to do more to support people who are struggling to balance family and work
I 've heard from so many of you about the difficult choices you face and the stresses that you 're under
let 's have paid family leave , earned sick days
Let 's be sure we have affordable child care and debt-free college
How are we going to do it
We 're going to do it by having the wealthy pay their fair share and close the corporate loopholes
we tonight are on the stage together , Donald Trump and I
it 's good to be with you
We 're going to have a debate where we are talking about the important issues facing our country
You have to judge us , who can shoulder the immense , awesome responsibilities of the presidency , who can put into action the plans that will make your life better
I hope that I will be able to earn your vote on November 8th"

cqs.cq: Why should the government take money from people who have worked hard to earn it and give it to people who are struggling?
What makes you think that the wealthy are the only ones who have the money to pay for the things you are proposing?
If you are going to make a change, why would you want to keep the current system as a middle ground?
If you are so concerned about the wealthy, why do you want to be president?

CLINTON_21.input:
CLINTON: "nine million people lost their jobs
Five million people lost their homes
$ 13 trillion in family wealth was wiped out
Now , we have come back from that abyss
it has not been easy
we 're now on the precipice of having a potentially much better economy
the last thing we need to do is to go back to the policies that failed us in the first place
Independent experts have looked at what I 've proposed
looked at what Donald 's proposed
I intend to get it done
Take clean energy
Some country is going to be the clean- energy superpower of the 21st century
Donald thinks that climate change is a hoax perpetrated by the Chinese
I think it 's real"

cqs.cq: If the climate change is real, why are you not addressing the issue of the Chinese government being the main polluter?
If climate change is as big of a threat as you claim, why would you want to continue to make the US a major player in the global economy and a global power?
If you believe that climate change is real, then why do you want to build more pipelines and drill for oil?
If you think it is real, why are you not willing to do something to stop it?

CLINTON_223_1.input:
CLINTON: "Let 's talk about two important issues that were briefly mentioned by Donald
first , NATO
NATO as a military alliance has something called Article 5
you know the only time it 's ever been invoked ?
After 9/11 , when the 28 nations of NATO said that they would go to Afghanistan with us to fight terrorism
something that they still are doing by our side
With respect to Iran , when I became secretary of state , Iran was weeks away from having enough nuclear material to form a bomb
They had mastered the nuclear fuel cycle under the Bush administration
They had built covert facilities
They had stocked them with centrifuges that were whirling away
we had sanctioned them"

cqs.cq: What if Iran was just trying to enrich uranium for civilian purposes and not for weapons?
If Clinton is correct, then why did Trump say that Iran was a threat and Obama said that Iran was a threat?
If the sanctions did not work, why would you think that a new set of sanctions would?
Are you going to get into the details of what sanctions do and do not do to prevent the proliferation of nuclear weapons?

CLINTON_223_2.input:
CLINTON: "I voted for every sanction against Iran when I was in the Senate
it was n't enough
I spent a year-and-a-half putting together a coalition that included Russia and China to impose the toughest sanctions on Iran
 we did drive them to the negotiating table
my successor , John Kerry , and President Obama got a deal that put a lid on Iran 's nuclear program without firing a single shot
That 's diplomacy
That 's coalition-building
That 's working with other nations
That 's not good judgment"

cqs.cq: Why is it bad judgment to see the US as a threat to Iran and to not want to make a deal that would make the US a threat to Iran?
Can you show us some of the examples of the good judgement you have shown in your time in the Senate?
If so, why not do the same with North Korea?
Why do you think that Trump's decision to pull out of the Iran deal was bad judgment?

CLINTON_225.input: CLINTON: "That is not the right temperament to be commander-in- chief , to be taunted"

cqs.cq: Do you have any evidence of him being taunted by a world leader that was more powerful than him?
Do you have any evidence to support that a president should not be taunted and mocked by foreign leaders?
Why is taunting the president, or the leader of a country, not a good quality for a leader to have?
If someone is going to get taunted, should not the person doing the taunting be the one to stop it?

CLINTON_231.input:
CLINTON: "in fact , his cavalier attitude about nuclear weapons is so deeply troubling
That is the number-one threat we face in the world
it becomes particularly threatening if terrorists ever get their hands on any nuclear material"

cqs.cq: If so, why is that a problem with him and not with Clinton?
Does Clinton have any evidence to back up this claim that terrorists are trying to get their hands on nuclear material?
But why would he want to use a nuclear weapon on a city when it would be a horrible thing to do to his own people?
If the threat of nuclear war is so deeply troubling, why is Clinton still supporting a president who has threatened to use nuclear weapons?

CLINTON_235.input:
CLINTON: "It 's a good one , though
It well describes the problem"

cqs.cq: What if the problem is that they are not smart enough to understand what the problem is?
Do you have a scientific source that confirms that men and women are inherently different in their emotional needs and desires?
Are you arguing that people are racist because they do not agree with you on this issue?
So is your point that the problem is that they are not following the teachings of the religion, or that the teachings of the religion are the problem?

CLINTON_244_2.input:
CLINTON: "If he 's going to criticize a deal that has been very successful in giving us access to Iranian facilities that we never had before , then he should tell us what his alternative would be
it 's like his plan to defeat ISIS
the only secret is that he has no plan
He says it 's a secret plan
we need to be more precise in how we talk about these issues
People around the word follow our presidential campaigns so closely , trying to get hints about what we will do
Can they rely on us ?
Are we going to lead the world with strength and in accordance with our values ?
That 's what I intend to do
I intend to be a leader of our country that people can count on , both here at home and around the world
to make decisions that will further peace and prosperity
also stand up to bullies , whether they 're abroad or at home
We can not let those who would try to destabilize the world to interfere with American interests and security"

cqs.cq: If so, what does it say about you if you think you can make a better deal than the one Clinton made?
Can you provide evidence that Trump would destabilize the world?
If you want to say that a country is a bully, then how do you justify the fact that the US has been involved in over 100 military conflicts since 1945?
Why would you not want to have the same kind of diplomacy with Iran that you have with North Korea?

CLINTON_25.input:
CLINTON: "it 's important that we grip this and deal with it , both at home and abroad
here 's what we can do
We can deploy a half a billion more solar panels
We can have enough clean energy to power every home
We can build a new modern electric grid
That 's a lot of jobs
that 's a lot of new economic activity
 I 've tried to be very specific about what we can and should do
I am determined that we 're going to get the economy really moving again , building on the progress we 've made over the last eight years , but never going back to what got us in trouble in the first place"

cqs.cq: What if the jobs that are created by the new solar panels and modern electric grid are in a state that is not favorable to her?
So you do not believe that climate change is a real issue?
If the economy is the problem, why are you not running for president to fix the economy instead of running to be president of the world?
If you have a plan to make the economy better, why not just put it out there?

CLINTON_37.input:
CLINTON: " Some of them I voted for
The biggest one, a multinational one known as CAFTA, I voted against
I hold the same standards as I look at all of these trade deals
let's not assume that trade is the only challenge we have in the economy
it is a part of it
I'm going to have a special prosecutor
We're going to enforce the trade deals we have, and we're going to hold people accountable
When I was secretary of state, we actually increased American exports globally 30 percent
We increased them to China 50 percent
 know how to really work to get new jobs and to get exports that helped to create more new jobs"

cqs.cq: Why would you not want to increase the exports of the US to China?
So why is it that you want to make the trade deal with China a priority over the other trade deals that you want to renegotiate?
If you want to make a case against her, how does this make her worse than Trump or Biden?
If the trade agreements are so bad, why did the US increase exports under the Obama administration?

CLINTON_39.input:
CLINTON: "I've been a senator, Donald
...
You haven't done it.
 I have been a secretary of state
And I have done a lot"

cqs.cq: So why should we trust you with the job of President of the United States?
Do you have any evidence that being a secretary of state is more difficult than being a senator?
If you were to look at the qualifications of a Secretary of State, why would you think that being a Senator would not count?
Are you suggesting that being a Secretary of State is a harder job than being a Senator?

CLINTON_55.input:
CLINTON: "There are different views about what's good for our country, our economy, and our leadership in the world
it's important to look at what we need to do to get the economy going again
new jobs with rising incomes, investments, not in more tax cuts that would add $5 trillion to the debt"

cqs.cq: If we can do that by giving corporations tax cuts, then why not do it?
So what do you think the economy needs to do to get going again?
If you are talking about a tax cut, why would it add to the debt if it is not a tax cut that is paid for?
If you see no difference in the policy between the two, why are you supporting the one who would not create the jobs you claim you want to create?

CLINTON_57.input:
CLINTON: "you have no plan
I have written a book about it. It's called "Stronger Together."
You can pick it up tomorrow at a bookstore
we need to have strong growth , fair growth , sustained growth
We also have to look at how we help families balance the responsibilities at home and the responsibilities at business
we have a very robust set of plans
people have looked at both of our plans , have concluded that mine would create 10 million jobs and yours would lose us 3.5 million jobs , and explode the debt which would have a recession"

cqs.cq: If you can do better, why have you not created a plan to do so?
Do you have a link to the plan that would create 10 million jobs?
If Clinton is saying that Trump has no plan, then why does she have to keep mentioning hers?
If you have a plan to create 10 million jobs, then why do you need the government to do it?

CLINTON_66.input:
CLINTON: "what I have proposed would not add a penny to the debt
 your plans would add $ 5 trillion to the debt
What I have proposed would cut regulations and streamline them for small businesses
What I have proposed would be paid for by raising taxes on the wealthy
they have made all the gains in the economy
it 's time that the wealthy and corporations paid their fair share to support this country"

cqs.cq: If your tax proposal is going to be paid for by raising taxes on the wealthy, why would they be opposed to it?
Do you have any evidence that shows corporations are not paying their fair share of taxes?
Why is it fair to punish the rich for the sins of the rich?
Why should we tax the rich to support the poor?

CLINTON_6_1.input:
CLINTON: "we are 5 percent of the world 's population ; we have to trade with the other 95 percent
we need to have smart , fair trade deals
We also , though , need to have a tax system that rewards work and not just financial transactions
the kind of plan that Donald has put forth would be trickle-down economics all over again
it would be the most extreme version , the biggest tax cuts for the top percent of the people in this country than we 've ever had
trumped-up trickle-down , because that 's exactly what it would be
That is not how we grow the economy
We just have a different view about what 's best for growing the economy , how we make investments that will actually produce jobs and rising incomes
we come at it from somewhat different perspectives
Donald was very fortunate in his life , and that 's all to his benefit"

cqs.cq: If he was so fortunate, then why is he so opposed to raising taxes on the wealthy?
Do you have any evidence to support that Trump was not born with a silver spoon in his mouth?
If you believe that a person is inherently superior because of their race, how can you justify the idea that a black person is just as good as a white person?
Do you think Donald was very fortunate to be born into a wealthy family and be able to inherit his father's wealth?

CLINTON_6_2.input:
CLINTON: "He started his business with $ 14 million , borrowed from his father
he really believes that the more you help wealthy people , the better off we 'll be and that everything will work out from there
I do n't buy that
I have a different experience
My father was a small-businessman
He worked really hard
He printed drapery fabrics on long tables, where he pulled out those fabrics and he went down with a silkscreen and dumped the paint in and took the squeegee and kept going
what I believe is the more we can do for the middle class, the more we can invest in you, your education, your skills, your future
the better we will be off and the better we'll grow
That's the kind of economy I want us to see again"

cqs.cq: So what makes you think that the economy is better off if we raise taxes and give the money to the middle class?
So if you really think that the middle class is the key to the economy, why are you spending so much time talking about the wealthy and their taxes?
If a poor black kid grows up to be a billionaire, why does he have to pay more taxes than a white billionaire?
If the economy is not doing well, why would we want to raise taxes on the rich?

CLINTON_85.input:
CLINTON: "let 's start the clock again , Lester
We 've looked at your tax proposals
I do n't see changes in the corporate tax rates or the kinds of proposals you 're referring to that would cause the repatriation , bringing back of money that 's stranded overseas
I happen to support that"

cqs.cq: If you support bringing back money that is stranded overseas, why would you not support bringing back money that is stranded in a pension plan?
If so, why would he be opposed to a tax cut that would bring that money back to the US?
If that is the case, then why is the Clinton campaign saying it is not going to happen?
If you believe that the current tax system is causing that money to be stranded overseas, why would you want to keep the current tax system?

CLINTON_87.input:
CLINTON: "I happen to support that in a way that will actually work to our benefit
when I look at what you have proposed , you have what is called now the Trump loophole
it would so advantage you and the business you do"

cqs.cq: So if you think this is a bad idea, why do you want to keep it as a loophole?
So why do you keep saying that you are going to close the loophole that you created and is only good for you?
Why would a loophole in the tax code that allows you to avoid paying taxes be a bad thing?
Are you saying that you would create a law that would only benefit you and your business?

CLINTON_92.input:
CLINTON: "it is
trumped-up trickle-down
Trickle-down did not work
It got us into the mess we were in , in 2008 and 2009
Slashing taxes on the wealthy has n't worked
a lot of really smart , wealthy people know that
they are saying , hey , we need to do more to make the contributions we should be making to rebuild the middle class
I do n't think top-down works in America
building the middle class , investing in the middle class , making college debt-free so more young people can get their education , helping people refinance their—their debt from college at a lower rate
Those are the kinds of things that will really boost the economy
Broad-based , inclusive growth is what we need in America , not more advantages for people at the very top"

cqs.cq: Why is the economy only good if it is broad based and inclusive?
Do you have a source to back up the claim that slashing taxes on the wealthy has not worked?
If you really want to help the middle class, why not give them a tax cut instead of raising their taxes?
If you think the wealthy are not paying their fair share of taxes, then why not raise the tax rate on the wealthy?

CL_57.input:
CL: "Well, both sides of the transaction suffer as a result of ignoring moral hazard
because moral hazard is a natural part of the process of lending and borrowing
And if you suppress it, then in fact you're in a situation where the wealth that you look like you're generating is fool’s gold, not real wealth at all."

cqs.cq: If the value of the wealth is fool’s gold, why would you want to see it go to waste and not be used for anything?
What makes you think that there is a moral hazard problem here?
If so, then why do you want to allow the banks to keep making money from people who can barely pay back the loan?
If you view it as the latter, why would you view it as a bad thing?

Doctor-Mom_205.input:
Doctor-Mom: "I would support a full ban of peanut products on any airline.
Peanut reactions can be life threatening.
An individual doesn't have to consume the product to have a life threatening reaction.
They can have contact or inhalation reactions.
Restricting to certain flights is not enough,
as residue can be rampant.
Providing buffer zones is a thoughtful gesture,
but from a practical point of view does not work.
With so many food choices available, why are peanuts a necessary choice?
I am a physician , and author on the subject.
I have free food allergy online support forums with 3000 members.
http://www.drmomsallergyrx.com/
I would be more than willing to work with you in any way on this decision making process.
The allergic community is so grateful that you are allowing our voices to be heard.
The decision you are considering could save many lives."

cqs.cq: If you feel so strongly about it, why not just ban peanuts in general and not just on airplanes?
Do you have any evidence to suggest that peanut allergies are increasing in frequency or severity?
If you are so passionate about this, why are you not advocating for a ban in schools as well?
Why would you want to make flying more expensive and less accessible to people?

Elmattador__92.input:
Elmattador: "you must have missed the GOP debates"
 < this message is answering to > 
Bigtwinkie: "This debate has honestly been making me uncomfortable
its been way too hostile
Its like listening to mom and dad fight in the kitchen while your hide under the covers in your room
 all they succeed at is making the entire panel seem unlikable
the democratic nominee will be bleeding votes no matter who wins"

cqs.cq: If they are so unlikable, why are they getting so much attention and why do they get so many votes?
Do you have any evidence that the Democratic nominee will lose votes because of this debate?
If so, why do you care what the Democratic nominee is going to do to the Republican nominee?
So what do you think is the reason for that?

FoodAllergyMom_199_1.input:
FoodAllergyMom: "My child is 2 years old and he is severely allergic to peanuts, tree nuts, egg and milk.
My son has reacted to airborne particles from someone opening a bag of nuts near him.
My husband and I used to be world traveler's and dreamed of traveling with our son.
It is heartbreaking to think that our child will not get to experience the world, or if he does it may cost him his life.
What about when he gets older and his job requires him to fly across the country in a weekend?
Should he have to risk his life so he can work in his possible future dream job?
This is a disability, no question about it.
We are talking about being in the air with peanut particles being circulated through the cabin and possible no place to land for hours.
An EpiPen only last 15 minutes.
Peanut allergy is unpredictable.
The first reaction could be mild
and the second could cause your blood pressure to drop like a rocket, your throat to close up and your heart to stop beating."

cqs.cq: If your child is so allergic that they can die from just being near someone who has eaten peanuts, why not have them avoid being near anyone who eats peanuts?
What is the difference between a peanut allergy and a peanut intolerance?
If a peanut allergy is so severe, then why is it not as common as other allergies like gluten intolerance or lactose intolerance?
If your child is allergic to peanuts, then why are you making a huge deal about them being in the air?

Frequent-Flyer_157.input:
Frequent-Flyer: "I have sympathy for those with peanut allergies,
but banning peanuts from flights via a DOT regulation seems to go too far.
Perhaps advocacy groups for those who are peanutallergic will approach the major carriers to voluntarily set aside seating blocks that are reserved for allergy sufferers, and nonsufferers who are willing to agree not to eat peanuts while sitting in that particular block.
As someone who suffers from a medical condition which requires me to carry my "rescue" medication with me everywhere I go,
I think that if the risk to an allergy sufferer is deemed to be significant, then they should
consider alternate travel methods other than flying,
ensure they have sufficient "rescue" medication to last the entire time they might be stuck in an aircraft,
they should wear appropriate clothing / face masks to minimize exposed skin and inhalation risk.
Requiring other passengers to forgo their "right" to eat peanuts so as to accommodate the "right" of allergy sufferers to fly seems a bit much,
particularly if the allergy sufferers don't fly often, anyway."

cqs.cq: If you are flying on a flight that has a peanut allergy sufferer, do you think that the person with the allergy should have to change seats?
Does it matter if they are not frequent flyers?

If you have a medical condition that requires you to carry a device that could potentially save your life, why would you be expected to be the one to take steps to avoid a potentially life threatening situation?
Why would you want to be in a situation where you could potentially cause death to someone else?

Glblwrmingisfak__552.input:
Glblwrmingisfak: "What argument?
Nobody proposes common sense gun solutions
The DOJ over a decade ago already determined that an assault weapons ban won't do shit for addressing homicide rates in the US
It is not a solution for any of our problems
Bernie should know
he clearly isn't stupid"

cqs.cq: Why do you think Bernie is stupid for wanting to ban assault weapons if the DOJ already said it won t do shit to address homicide rates?
So why did Bernie propose it as a solution to the problem of gun violence?
If Bernie is not stupid, then why is he pushing for an assault weapons ban?
If Bernie Sanders is so against gun control, why does he support a ban on assault weapons?

HOLT_126.input:
HOLT: "Stop-and-frisk was ruled unconstitutional in New York
it largely singled out black and Hispanic young men"

cqs.cq: Why do you think that is if it is truly unconstitutional?
Do you have a source to back up the claim that stop and frisk is racist?
If the law is unconstitutional, why does it matter how it is enforced?
If the goal is to stop crime, then why is it a problem if it is mostly black and Hispanic young men being stopped?

HOLT_239.input:
HOLT: "Which leads to my next question
we enter our last segment here on the , still on the subject of securing America
On nuclear weapons , President Obama reportedly considered changing the nation 's longstanding policy on first use
Do you support the current policy ?
Mr. Trump , you have two minutes on that"

cqs.cq: Why would you want to be the first to use a weapon that can destroy the entire world?
Is there a reason why you would not want to make the use of nukes a last resort?
If the US is not going to use nuclear weapons first, why would they be a deterrent?
If we are to assume that you are right, then why would the US ever use nuclear weapons?

HOLT_94.input:
HOLT: "we 're talking about the burden that Americans have to pay , yet you have not released your tax returns
the reason nominees have released their returns for decades is so that voters will know if their potential president owes money to—who he owes it to and any business conflicts
Do n't Americans have a right to know if there are any conflicts of interest"

cqs.cq: Why would we need to know what kind of business you have if you do not owe money to anyone?
Do you have any evidence that Trump has any business conflicts of interest?
Why would they need to know if the president has a conflict of interest if the president isn’t the one making the laws?
If you are saying that the American public has a right to know if there are any conflicts of interest, then why would it matter if the nominee owes money to someone or not?

Helen__66.input:
Helen: "they’re not able to impose the right sort of levels
and within that bracket I would certainly put families who are living with very high levels of aggression and violence, who are terrorising communities
So, yes I’d agree with that
But I would also say that there are other families, where actually they do need a great deal of help
it’s right to intervene
and actually you can help them get back on their feet and able to parent their children effectively"

cqs.cq: What if the parents are unable to be helped and the children are better off in foster care?
Why should we intervene if the family is not causing harm to the children?
If you believe the state should intervene to help families who are struggling to parent their children effectively, why not intervene in all families?
Why should we intervene and help the ones who do not need it if they are not harming anyone?

17th_knight__247.input:
17th: "They should get the coverage
They are here
they work
they are a part of this society
Fuck off with your xenophobia"
 < this message is answering to > 
reaper527: "now you have a field of democrat presidential candidates supporting it
republicans used to get mocked and laughed at when they said that illegal immigrants would be getting obamacare coverage"

cqs.cq: So you are saying that Republicans are wrong to say that illegal immigrants will get obamacare coverage?
Why should illegal immigrants get free health care?
Why are you suddenly going to care about the legality of someone if they are going to get free healthcare?
What is wrong with illegal immigrants getting obamacare coverage?

AFCHF_154.input:
AFCHF: "DOT should set maximum tarmac delay trigger.
It then should apply to ALL AIRLINES and ALL CLASSES of AIRCRAFT.
The airlines need to make a legal committment (contract of carriage).
Deplaneing without CBP screening IS a viable option.
As a military member, I have done this many times during overseas contract flights.
I realize this is customs rather than airport security, but the concept is the same.
Allow passengers to deplane during gate holds,
but require them to remain in the immediate area.
This is no different than an openended delay prior to boarding."

cqs.cq: If so, then why not just deplane everyone and then have them come back in when it is safe to do so?
What is the benefit of deplaning and staying in the immediate area when you have to go back on the plane anyway?
Why would you not want to be able to board and deplane at the same time as everyone else?
What is the harm of keeping passengers on the plane for a longer period of time?

AK-traveler_186.input:
AK-traveler: "Airlines should not be allowed to charge for items necessary because of factors out of the passengers control.
Seat size and configuration (arm and leg room) should be addressed as a health issue.
The inflight magazines show exercises passengers should do at their seats to prevent deep vein thrombosis
but there isn't enough room to do them.
And finally, I think it is unfair if not criminal and discriminatory to charge exorbinant fees for carrying your pet onboard with you.
The carrier is handled as a carry on bag solely by me,
the airline doesn't do anything
yet they carage $100 or more each way."

cqs.cq: If you are flying with a pet, why do you need to take it on the plane with you?
Do you have a scientific study that shows that a lack of leg room is a health risk for people?
So why should you get to bring a pet on a plane that the airline has to pay for the extra space to accommodate?
Why would it be so bad for the airline to charge $100 to bring a pet on the plane?

AllergyDad_200.input:
AllergyDad: "As a parent of a child with severe lifethreatening allergies to peanuts and treenuts, the thought of getting on an airplane today is frightening.
So much so, that it is strictly avoided.
It is not worth risking my child's life to fly on an airplane.
A recent study reveals that 1 in 3 airplane reactions was anaphylaxis
(Allergic Living Magazine).
I don't like those odds.
The substitution of cashews, walnuts, or other tree nuts is not a viable option,
as they pose the same risks as peanuts.
A large number of people who are allergic to peanuts are also allergic to tree nuts,
plus they are typically processed in a plant that also processes peanuts.
If there were a ban on peanut and tree nut products on flights, it would open the world to my son.
He didn't choose to be allergic,
but he is.
So true.
We are not talking about sensitivity, being offended, not liking the smell, etc.;
we are talking about life.
There are a lot of things that are banned from airplanes that can cause death to someone.
In the case of my son, a peanut can have the same result.
I urge the DOT to issue the ban,
and make traveling safe for everyone."

cqs.cq: If you are so concerned about the health of your child, why are you flying on a plane?
Why would you think that banning peanuts on planes would make the flights safer?
If you are allergic to peanuts, why would you even want to fly on a plane?
If the risk of an allergic reaction is so high, then why not ban all food on flights?

AngelComa__638.input:
AngelComa: "Funny, I thought he did good
They get timed responses
his plan is all there
He can't talk about everything in the plan
Must be how used you are to politicians saying things and not having a plan"
 < this message is answering to > 
Punchee: "That was a weird moment in American debate history. "Yo check my website. Shit's on there.""

cqs.cq: Does the fact that he said it multiple times make it any less true?
Do you have any evidence to support the claim that he said that?
Why is it that the candidate who made this statement is the one who is criticized for it and not the other candidate who was debating him?
So why would he put it on his website if he thought it would be a bad idea?

Antanagoge_104.input:
Antanagoge: "The airline industry can not be left to selfmonitor this.
Studies have shown that the quality of information from airline customer service department is highly variable and, in some cases, incomplete or inaccurate.
The psychological effects of this, combined with the risk of death, are significant.
Stories told by families of vacations never taken, of midair retraction of the promise by the airline that peanuts would not be served, of public humiliation of peanutallergic individuals and their family by airline staff, and of serious reactions in flight, abound."

cqs.cq: If you really want to avoid peanuts, why are you flying with an airline that serves peanuts?
Do you have any evidence that this is a problem in the airline industry?
If they really care about their safety, why would they not just be honest about the peanuts?
Are you suggesting that airlines should be held liable for death caused by a peanut allergy?

Antanagoge_111.input:
Antanagoge: "The opponents of accommodations are well aware that studies have been published in the journals of the American Academy of Allergy Asthma and Immunology, the American Medical Association, and the American College of Allergy, Asthma and Immunology, not to mention medical associations in other countries.
They can purchase full text access for themselves,
but they already have a prejudgment against the researchers and their conclusions,
so why bother?
There was a moment on the board when the moderators asked for a discussion of a hypothetical compromise position.
But those demanding funerals before entertaining even a compromise position muted that.
That is sad.
There are several others on the board with some good reasonable ideas.
It's fairly clear that meanspiritedness abounds, here
probably as a result of emphasis in current American politics on the potential for influence of minority interests and needs.
But some of the people on this board  calling for funerals before advancing the discussion  give new meaning to the Founders' fears of the tyranny of the majority."

cqs.cq: If you want to be fair and equal, why not make it so that everyone has to follow the rules and not just the minority?
Do you have a source to back up your claim that the majority of people on the board are calling for funerals before advancing the discussion?
If the majority of the people in the country are white, why should we not have a government that is run by the majority of the people in the country?
But why do you think they are more entitled to be heard than others?

Antanagoge_227.input:
Antanagoge: "Peanut allergens are indeed present in the recirculated air in the aircraft cabin.
This study, "Recovery of peanut allergens from ventilation filters of commercial airliners," ? conducted "to help address whether peanutsensitive travelers are exposed to peanut aeroallergans during airline flights on which peanuts are served" ? resulted in the conclusion that "that peanut allergens can be eluted from ventilation system filters in commercial airliners. The most likely source of these allergens are the peanuts served during flights." ?
http://download.journals.elsevierhealth.com/pdfs/journals/00916749/PIIS0091674996811791.pdf"
 < this message is answering to > 
Mulder: "Apparently Samsmom is the ignorant one.
She attacks what she clearly does not understand.
If her child has a true peanut allergy that is so severe, he shouldn't be flying,
since her argument is that any contact with peanut dust or oil would cause anaphylactic shock.
Since that possibility is very real even outside an airline cabin,
she's making her own argument for living in a bubble.
Facts are stubborn things,
and one of those facts is that the air onboard an airliner is cleaner than in most public buildings,
so there's very little, if any, real risk involved in flying on a jet where peanuts have been consumed before or are even being served now.
Another stubborn fact is that you can be desensitized to peanut allergies,
but if you're unwilling to do it, don't blame others for not bending to your petty fears.
Nobody has studied this subject,
so there's no hard data.
But we do know that the air onboard an airliner is much cleaner than people think.
Only one confirmed death onboard an airliner has been reported,
but it may have been as far back as 1998,
and it was an Eastern European airline."

cqs.cq: If you are allergic to peanuts, then why would you fly on an airplane that has peanuts on it?
Are you aware of the fact that peanut allergies are a growing health problem and the death rate from them has increased dramatically in recent years?
If the peanut allergen is not in the air, then how is the allergy triggered?
Do you have any evidence that the death was related to peanut consumption?

Antanagoge_239.input:
Antanagoge: "Is it really possible that all blindly partisan advocates of the peanut in this context eat peanuts and only peanuts?
That they are overtaken by such a compulsion to consume peanut while flying that they lose sight of all other priorities?
That they are unable to stop using their peanut  the one dragon they can't put to sleep  to create a sense of pleasure and comfort?
These sound like essential symptoms of disordered eating and addiction, which, in all likelihood, derive from some longstanding issues.
The remedy is to avoid the substance in question.... "just say 'no'" ? to your peanuts.
Serving/eating peanuts on airplanes has risen to the level of a public health menace, as had tobacco smoking.
Again, the only prudent course of action is to require that distribution of peanut on airplanes be discontinued."
 < this message is answering to > 
howie: "Mulder is right on point.
Most food allergies are completely imagined.
An overly anxious parent gets it in her head that little jimmy might have had a hive after someone had peanuts in his vicinity,
and now he's "deathly allergic".
Has ANYONE ever actually died on a plane from peanuts (other than by choking on them)?
I sincerely doubt it.
Peanuts are incredibly nutritious,
almost universally enjoyed,
and quite filling in a small serving.
Simply put, pound for pound there is no better food on the planet.
This whole antipeanut hysteria is ridiculous!
Leave my peanuts alone!
If you are one of the incredibly rare people that have an actual medically diagnosed severe allergy to this wonderful food, then you better never leave the house because peanuts are everywhere.
You certainly should not be flying."

cqs.cq: If peanuts are so safe, why do airlines have to have emergency kits on hand for peanut allergies?
Do you have any evidence that this is not a real allergy?
If peanuts are so good for you, why would airlines want to stop serving them?
But what if peanuts were causing people to have heart attacks or strokes?

Bill_106.input:
Bill: "I run a retail business.
If I changed my prices every few minutes or hours like the airline does or charge my customers different prices on the same day.
They would probably never come back and call the better business bureau.
And they wonder why so much distrust and angry customers.
Recently I wrote to one airline that had a ticket price of around $198. but then listed the taxes at something like $400.00 extra.
I told them it was Bait and Add on.
Similar to some retail stores that Bait customers with low price and then Switch to higher priced goods.
It is illegal and called Bait and Switch.
The airlines or some ticket sellers are guilty of lies.
Taxes are never higher than the price of the ticket.
I spend hours trying to buy a ticket without getting ripped off.
It should not be this difficult.
And one way fare should be half of a RT not higher than RT.
hey force us to buy RT and then use only the one way portion."

cqs.cq: So if you really think the airline is being deceptive and ripping you off, why do you keep flying with them?
Why do you feel airlines should be forced to sell one way tickets at half the price of a round trip ticket?
If the airline is making a profit by selling a round trip, why would it matter to the airline if you only used one of those trips?
Why should airlines be forced to sell one way tickets at a lower price if they are not making a profit off of them?

CF_29.input:
CF: "Yes, but what I'm saying is we shouldn’t encourage it for ourselves either
That’s my point.
And then finally, if I could just ask you, there’s a danger I think when you kind of say, “The poor are the ones who suffer. The rich are the bad guys.”
It is the case that some of the greatest examples of social progress over the years have come from well-off rich people, banks and so on, investing productively
Isn’t the problem that the only thing the banks have done is kind of consumer credit?
What they should have been doing, what they could be doing, and what they haven’t got the nerve to do, is not loaning enough
They should actually be taking more risk and giving more money out"

cqs.cq: If the banks were doing that, why do you think the poor would have less of a problem with it?
Can you explain why you think the banks are not loaning enough money?
If so, why should we expect banks to do that if it is not profitable?
So if you believe that the banks are being reckless, why would you want to encourage them to be more reckless?

CF_46.input:
CF: "Yes, but I'm suggesting that that was a political strategy, a way of covering things up
All I'm saying is that I think the people who took the sub-prime mortgages were the beneficiaries – and now the sufferers – of what I was saying is a policy
When you think about it now, I actually find it frustrating when I'm trying to talk to people about the real state the economy is in
And people sort of assume like everything can just carry on, and all that you need is a kind of credit based consumer thing
“Well, do we have to have cuts? Do we have to have this? Do we have to have that?”
And you do actually want to say, “Money doesn’t grow on trees.”"

cqs.cq: If the economy is in such a bad state, then why are the rich getting richer and the poor getting poorer?
Do you have any evidence that there is a lot of people who are like you who are just saying that the economy is in bad shape and we need to cut spending?
So why is that a problem if the government has to borrow money to pay for things?
If you want to say that, then why are you not saying it?

CLINTON_103.input:
CLINTON: "I think you 've seen another example of bait-and- switch here
For 40 years , everyone running for president has released their tax returns
You can go and see nearly , I think , 39 , 40 years of our tax returns
everyone has done it
We know the IRS has made clear there is no prohibition on releasing it when you 're under audit
you 've got to ask yourself , why wo n't he release his tax returns ?
there may be a couple of reasons
First , maybe he 's not as rich as he says he is
Second , maybe he 's not as charitable as he claims to be
maybe he does n't want the American people , all of you watching tonight , to know that he 's paid nothing in federal taxes
the only years that anybody 's ever seen were a couple of years when he had to turn them over to state authorities when he was trying to get a casino license
they showed he did n't pay any federal income tax"

cqs.cq: If the reason is that he paid no income tax, then why is that a bad thing?
Do you have any evidence to support this claim?
If he paid no income tax, why would he have to pay capital gains tax?
Why would someone who is a billionaire want to release his tax returns to the public?

CLINTON_123_1.input:
CLINTON: "Race remains a significant challenge in our country
Unfortunately, race still determines too much
often determines where people live
determines what kind of education in their public schools they can get,
it determines how they're treated in the criminal justice system
We've just seen those two tragic examples in both Tulsa and Charlotte
we've got to do several things at the same time
We have to restore trust between communities and the police
We have to work to make sure that our police are using the best training, the best techniques, that they're well prepared to use force only when necessary
Everyone should be respected by the law, and everyone should respect the law
Right now, that's not the case in a lot of our neighborhoods
I have, ever since the first day of my campaign, called for criminal justice reform"

cqs.cq: If so, how does that justify the deaths of black men who have been killed by police officers who are simply doing their jobs?
Do you think this is a racial issue or a socioeconomic issue?
If you believe the system is so racist, why would you want to reform it?
And if we should strive to stop all killings then why would the implement of this murder be spared if it causes a very large number of deaths but was intended to cause none?

CLINTON_123_2.input:
CLINTON: "I've laid out a platform that I think would begin to remedy some of the problems we have in the criminal justice system
we also have to recognize, in addition to the challenges that we face with policing, there are so many good, brave police officers who equally want reform
we have to bring communities together in order to begin working on that as a mutual goal
we've got to get guns out of the hands of people who should not have them
The gun epidemic is the leading cause of death of young African- American men, more than the next nine causes put together
we have to do two things
We have to restore trust
We have to work with the police
We have to make sure they respect the communities and the communities respect them
we have to tackle the plague of gun violence
which is a big contributor to a lot of the problems that we're seeing today"

cqs.cq: So if you think that the police are a plague, why would you want to keep them around?
What are you going to do about the gun violence that is caused by the police?
If that is true, then why did she not take any action on gun control in her 8 years as President?
So if you were to pass a law making it illegal to own a gun, would that make the police less likely to kill black people?

CLINTON_130_1.input:
CLINTON: "I've heard Donald say this at his rallies
it's really unfortunate that he paints such a dire negative picture of black communities in our country
the vibrancy of the black church
the black businesses that employ so many people
the opportunities that so many families are working to provide for their kids
There's a lot that we should be proud of and we should be supporting and lifting up
we do always have to make sure we keep people safe
There are the right ways of doing it
then there are ways that are ineffective
Stop-and-frisk was found to be unconstitutional
in part, because it was ineffective
It did not do what it needed to do
I believe in community policing
in fact, violent crime is one-half of what it was in 1991
Property crime is down 40 percent
We just don't want to see it creep back up
We've had 25 years of very good cooperation
there were some problems
some unintended consequences
Too many young African-American and Latino men ended up in jail for nonviolent offenses"

cqs.cq: If it is not a crime to have a gun in your house, why is it a crime to have a gun in your car?
Do you have a source that says that African Americans are more likely to commit crimes than any other group?
If you think that blacks are being unfairly targeted by law enforcement, why do you not think that blacks are being unfairly targeted by the criminal justice system?
Are you saying that you are against the justice system?

CLINTON_130_2.input:
CLINTON: "it's just a fact that if you're a young African-American man and you do the same thing as a young white man, you are more likely to be arrested, charged, convicted, and incarcerated
we've got to address the systemic racism in our criminal justice system
We cannot just say law and order
we have to come forward with a plan that is going to divert people from the criminal justice system
deal with mandatory minimum sentences, which have put too many people away for too long for doing too little
We need to have more second chance programs
I'm glad that we're ending private prisons in the federal system
I want to see them ended in the state system
You shouldn't have a profit motivation to fill prison cells with young Americans
here are some positive ways we can work on this
I believe strongly that commonsense gun safety measures would assist us
Right now—and this is something Donald has supported, along with the gun lobby—right now, we've got too many military- style weapons on the streets
this is something Donald has supported, along with the gun lobby
In a lot of places, our police are outgunned
We need comprehensive background checks
we need to keep guns out of the hands of those who will do harm
we finally need to pass a prohibition on anyone who's on the terrorist watch list from being able to buy a gun in our country
If you're too dangerous to fly, you are too dangerous to buy a gun
there are things we can do
we ought to do it in a bipartisan way"

cqs.cq: If you are saying that we need to change the criminal justice system to make it fairer, why are you saying that we should lock up more people?
Do you have any evidence that the current system is racist, and that it is not just a matter of people being poor and committing crimes?
If the criminal justice system is so racist, why would it be racist to say that a black person should be treated like a white person?
Why would you want to ban guns for people on a terrorist watch list if you believe in a 2nd amendment right to bear arms?

CLINTON_147.input:
CLINTON: "New York has done an excellent job
I give credit across the board going back two mayors, two police chiefs
it has worked
other communities need to come together to do what will work
one murder is too many
it is important that we learn about what has been effective
not go to things that sound good that really did not have the kind of impact that we would want
Who disagrees with keeping neighborhoods safe
no one should disagree about respecting the rights of young men who live in those neighborhoods
we need to do a better job of working, again, with the communities, faith communities, business communities, as well as the police to try to deal with this problem"

cqs.cq: If the police are doing a good job, why do they need to be reformed?
Why would he need to bring up the fact that no one disagrees with keeping neighborhoods safe?
If a black person is shot by a white police officer, is that an example of systemic racism?
Why is it so bad to have a law that is not enforced?

CLINTON_17.input:
CLINTON: "let 's stop for a second and remember where we were eight years ago
We had the worst financial crisis , the Great Recession
the worst since the 1930s
 slashed taxes on the wealthy
failed to invest in the middle class
took their eyes off of Wall Street
created a perfect storm
was in large part because of tax policies
Donald was one of the people who rooted for the housing crisis
...
 it did collapse"

cqs.cq: If the housing market collapsed, why would the wealthy be able to recover so much more quickly than the middle class?
Do you have evidence that Clinton has said this?
So why did Obama have a worse recovery than Reagan?
So if we are to believe the housing crisis was caused by the wealthy, why do we need to raise taxes on them?

CLINTON_176_1.input:
CLINTON: "cyber security, cyber warfare will be one of the biggest challenges facing the next president
clearly we're facing at this point two different kinds of adversaries
There are the independent hacking groups that do it mostly for commercial reasons to try to steal information that they can use to make money
increasingly, we are seeing cyber attacks coming from states, organs of states
The most recent and troubling of these has been Russia
There's no doubt now that Russia has used cyber attacks against all kinds of organizations in our country
I am deeply concerned about this
Donald's very praiseworthy of Vladimir Putin
Putin is playing a really tough, long game here
one of the things he's done is to let loose cyber attackers to hack into government files, to hack into personal files, hack into the Democratic National Committee"

cqs.cq: So why would Putin be doing this if it was going to make him look bad?
If you have evidence that the Russian government has been involved in the hacking of the DNC, why have you not released it?
If the Russians were hacking into the DNC for information on Hillary Clinton, why would they leave the evidence of that in a way that would be easily found by the FBI?
If you have evidence that they hacked into the Democratic National Committee, why did you not report it to the FBI?

CLINTON_176_2.input:
CLINTON: "we recently have learned that, you know, that this is one of their preferred methods of trying to wreak havoc and collect information
We need to make it very clear—whether it's Russia, China, Iran or anybody else—the United States has much greater capacity
we are not going to sit idly by and permit state actors to go after our information, our private-sector information or our public-sector information
 we're going to have to make it clear that we don't want to use the kinds of tools that we have
We don't want to engage in a different kind of warfare
we will defend the citizens of this country
 the Russians need to understand that
 they've been treating it as almost a probing, how far would we go, how much would we do
I was so shocked when Donald publicly invited Putin to hack into Americans
That is just unacceptable"

cqs.cq: If Putin is not trying to hack the US, then why is he hacking the US?
Do you have any evidence that Russia has hacked into any American elections?
If Russia is going to hack into the US, why would the US not want to hack back?
If you believe that the Russians are actively trying to interfere with our election, why are you going to give them a chance to do it again?

CLINTON_186.input:
CLINTON: "there are a number of issues that we should be addressing
I have put forth a plan to defeat ISIS
It does involve going after them online
we need to do much more with our tech companies to prevent ISIS and their operatives from being able to use the Internet to radicalize , even direct people in our country and Europe and elsewhere
eventually support our Arab and Kurdish partners to be able to actually take out ISIS in Raqqa
end their claim of being a Caliphate
We 're making progress
Our military is assisting in Iraq
we 're hoping that within the year we 'll be able to push ISIS out of Iraq
really squeeze them in Syria
we have to be cognizant of the fact that they 've had foreign fighters coming to volunteer for them
foreign money
foreign weapons
we have to make this the top priority
I would also do everything possible to take out their leadership
I was involved in a number of efforts to take out Al Qaida leadership when I was secretary of state
including , of course , taking out bin Laden
we need to go after Baghdadi , as well
make that one of our organizing principles
we 've got to defeat ISIS
we 've got to do everything we can to disrupt their propaganda efforts online"

cqs.cq: What if the job is one that will cause their illness to manifest and affect their job performance?
Do you have any evidence that ISIS propaganda is the primary driver of recruitment?
Why should we be doing anything about ISIS propaganda if we are not going to do anything about other propaganda efforts that are coming from other terrorist groups?
But what if the propaganda is true?

CLINTON_193.input:
CLINTON: "I hope the fact-checkers are turning up the volume and really working hard
Donald supported the invasion of Iraq
...
That is absolutely proved over and over again
...
He actually advocated for the actions we took in Libya
urged that Gadhafi be taken out
after actually doing some business with him one time
larger point—and he says this constantly—is George W. Bush made the agreement about when American troops would leave Iraq , not Barack Obama
 the only way that American troops could have stayed in Iraq is to get an agreement from the then-Iraqi government that would have protected our troops
the Iraqi government would not give that
let 's talk about the question you asked , Lester"

cqs.cq: If you are going to be honest about the facts, then why do you keep lying about them?
Are you saying that the Bush administration never had the ability to make an agreement that would have allowed troops to stay in Iraq?
If Clinton is just going to say the same thing about Trump, why do you need to keep bringing it up?
If you can prove that Clinton was right, why would you not want to do that?

CLINTON_199_1.input:
CLINTON: "That's the most important part of this
How do we prevent attacks
How do we protect our people
we've got to have an intelligence surge, where we are looking for every scrap of information
I was so proud of law enforcement in New York, in Minnesota, in New Jersey
 they responded so quickly, so professionally to the attacks that occurred by Rahami
they brought him down
we may find out more information
 he is still alive"

cqs.cq: If he is a terrorist, why would you want to keep him alive?
Do you have evidence that he was planning anything more than a single attack?
If the FBI was so confident in their investigation and had enough evidence to make an arrest, why did they need a warrant to search his home?
If we do find out more information, what will we do with it?

TRUMP_240_2.input:
TRUMP: "by the way , another one powerful is the worst deal I think I 've ever seen negotiated that you started is the Iran deal
Iran is one of their biggest trading partners
Iran has power over North Korea
when they made that horrible deal with Iran , they should have included the fact that they do something with respect to North Korea
they should have done something with respect to Yemen and all these other places
when asked to Secretary Kerry , why did n't you do that ?
Why did n't you add other things into the deal ?
One of the great giveaways of all time , of all time , including $ 400 million in cash
Nobody 's ever seen that before
That turned out to be wrong
It was actually $ 1.7 billion in cash
obviously , I guess for the hostages
It certainly looks that way
This is one of the worst deals ever made by any country in history
you say to yourself , why did n't they make the right deal ?
The deal with Iran will lead to nuclear problems
All they have to do is sit back 10 years , and they do n't have to do much"

cqs.cq: If you see the Iran deal as a bad deal, why do you think the Iran deal is bad?
Do you have any evidence to support your claim that the Iran nuclear deal is a bad deal?
If we are going to compare the Iran deal to other deals, what makes the Iran deal worse?
If you say the Iran deal is one of the worst deals in history, why do you still want to be friends with them?

TRUMP_249.input:
TRUMP: "I will go very quickly
I will tell you that Hillary will tell you to go to her website and read all about how to defeat ISIS
which she could have defeated by never having it
get going in the first place
Right now , it 's getting tougher and tougher to defeat them
they 're in more and more places
more and more states
more and more nations
it 's a big problem
as far as Japan is concerned , I want to help all of our allies
we are losing billions and billions of dollars
We can not be the policemen of the world
We can not protect countries all over the world"

cqs.cq: Why are we not allowed to protect countries all over the world?
Do you have any evidence to back up the claim that Japan is being protected by the US military?
If we can not protect countries all over the world, why do we have military bases all over the world?
If you are going to be the policeman of the world, why not be a good one?

TRUMP_251.input:
TRUMP: "they 're not paying us what we need
she 's got no business ability
We need heart
We need a lot of things
you have to have some basic ability
sadly , she does n't have that
All of the things that she 's talking about could have been taken care of during the last 10 years , let 's say , while she had great power
they were n't taken care of
if she ever wins this race , they wo n't be taken care of
she does n't have a presidential look
...
she does n't say that"

cqs.cq: If you do not believe she has a presidential look, then why do you think she should be president?
Can you point to a single example of her saying that?
Do you have any evidence that Trump believes that?
Why would you call her a woman if she does not have a womanly look?

TRUMP_253.input:
TRUMP: "She does n't have the look
She does n't have the stamina
I said she does n't have the stamina
I do n't believe she does have the stamina
To be president of this country , you need tremendous stamina
I just do n't think she has the presidential look
You asked me a question
You have to be able to negotiate our trade deals
You have to be able to negotiate , that 's right , with Japan , with Saudi Arabia
All you have to do is speak to them
Wait
...
Did you ask me a question
can you imagine , we 're defending Saudi Arabia
with all of the money they have , we 're defending them , and they 're not paying
You have so many different things you have to be able to do , and I do n't believe that Hillary has the stamina
The world
Hillary has experience , but it 's bad experience
it 's bad , bad experience
it 's the Iran deal that you 're so in love with , where we gave them $ 150 billion back
it 's the Iran deal
it 's anything you can—name
you almost ca n't name a good deal
She 's got experience , but it 's bad experience"

cqs.cq: If she has experience but it is bad experience, what does that say about her?
Do you have a source for that claim that Hillary Clinton is a narcissist?
If you see Hillary as a bad deal, why would you want to make her the president?
If you think she has bad experience, why would you want to get rid of her and hire someone with no experience at all?

TRUMP_26.input:
TRUMP: "She talks about solar panels
We invested in a solar company , our country
That was a disaster
They lost plenty of money on that one
I 'm a great believer in all forms of energy
we 're putting a lot of people out of work
Our energy policies are a disaster
Our country is losing so much in terms of energy
 in terms of paying off our debt
You ca n't do what you 're looking to do with $ 20 trillion in debt
The Obama administration , from the time they 've come in , is over 230 years ' worth of debt
he 's topped it
He 's doubled it in a course of almost eight years
seven-and-a-half years , to be semi- exact
We have to do a much better job at keeping our jobs
we have to do a much better job at giving companies incentives to build new companies or to expand
they 're not doing it
all you have to do is look at Michigan and look at Ohio and look at all of these places where so many of their jobs and their companies are just leaving
they 're gone
You 've been doing this for 30 years
Why are you just thinking about these solutions right now ?
For 30 years , you 've been doing it
now you 're just starting to think of solutions
I will bring back jobs
You ca n't bring back jobs"

cqs.cq: If you can bring back jobs, why would you only focus on the manufacturing jobs that have left the country?
Do you have any evidence to suggest that this will actually happen?

 < this message is answering to > 
citizen-s: "I strongly support cash compensation for bumping passengers with zeroprice tickets,
But to assure adequate compensation and prevent airlines gaming such a requirement,
compensation should be at the average (cash) ticket price for that service class on that flight.
DOT's proposed rule using the lowest fare ticket would encourage airlines to bump those with zeroprice tickets first,
since that cost would be lowest.
As long as they continue to offer tickets for miles, airlines should not be encouraged to treat passengers using those tickets as secondclass when it comes to bumping.
The growing scarcity of actual seats for miles
something that cries out for regulatory intervention
is bad enough."

cqs.cq: If so, then why not just make all tickets the same price?

cd38_220_2.input:
cd38: "The return flight is 6 ½ hours (plus commute time to the airport);
when time allows, I make something to bring on the flight,
but if my mother is having a bad day, that's not always possible.
On a recent trip, I didn't have time to eat anything at all the day I flew home; got stuck in traffic and barely made my flight (I was the last one on) so didn't have time to eat or buy anything at the airport; and as we started to taxi, the flight crew announced that we had a nut allergy on board, and that they (JB) would not be serving cashews and requested that we not eat any nuts we may have brought on board.
6 ½ hours feels pretty long at that point!
No, it didn't kill me,
but it does seem that if JB hadn't served cashews, the risks involved in one or two people eating nuts they may have brought with them would have been extremely, extremely small....
and, NOTHING in life is riskfree.
I understand that people want to minimize the risks for their loved ones,
but you cannot eliminate the risk completely, regardless of what legislation you put in place.
If I ate peanuts at the airport, didn't wash my hands, and then opened the rest room door on the plane immediately before a peanut allergy sufferer, that person could suffer a reaction.
I can support airlines not serving peanuts/peanut products,
thereby eliminating the most likely possible cause of a peanutrelated incident on a flight;
but not restrictions on what people may choose to eat."

cqs.cq: Why would you want to make it easier for someone to bring nuts on a flight if you are trying to keep the risk of someone dying from an allergy to a minimum?

If your mother is allergic to something, then why would you want to bring it on a plane and risk killing her?

citizen-s_134.input:
citizen-s: "DOT's objective in setting this rule should be to ELIMINATE all bumping, not merely achieve some (unspecified) reduction.
Regardless of how many caveats an airline might state in its contract terms, passengers neither want nor deserve a ticket for an oversold seat.
Bumping is a purely economic device that treats passengers as economic units devoid of humanity, like so many other aspects of airline behavior.
From that objective, it follows that there should be NO cap on compensation
and that the financial penalty to the airline should be strong enough to prevent bumping, not just keep it at some arbitrarily "acceptable" level.
The 100% of the total ticket price for expected arrival within 2 hours later is reasonable.
Compensation for a longer delay should be the GREATER of 200% of the total ticket cost or the passenger's demonstrable outofpocket costs resulting from the delay
(a) including any higher priced air ticket from the same or another carrier at the same class, and lodging, meals and incidentals at average prevailing prices in that metro area,
and (b) with the obligation on the passenger to minimize those costs by arranging, with good faith help from the airline, an alternate flight or other means to get him or her to the destination as soon as reasonably practical."

cqs.cq: If the airline is going to be forced to pay out $1000 or more for a ticket that was only sold for $300, why would they ever oversell?
Do you have a source for the claim that airlines are doing this to treat passengers as economic units devoid of humanity?
If you think that airlines are treating people as economic units, why are you not arguing that they should be treated as such in all cases?
So you are saying that the airline should be forced to pay for any additional flights, hotels, food, etc. that the bumped passenger incurred as a result of the bumping?

The growing scarcity of actual seats for miles
