howie_238.input:
howie: "Mulder is right on point.
Most food allergies are completely imagined.
An overly anxious parent gets it in her head that little jimmy might have had a hive after someone had peanuts in his vicinity,
and now he's "deathly allergic".
Has ANYONE ever actually died on a plane from peanuts (other than by choking on them)?
I sincerely doubt it.
Peanuts are incredibly nutritious,
almost universally enjoyed,
and quite filling in a small serving.
Simply put, pound for pound there is no better food on the planet.
This whole antipeanut hysteria is ridiculous!
Leave my peanuts alone!
If you are one of the incredibly rare people that have an actual medically diagnosed severe allergy to this wonderful food, then you better never leave the house because peanuts are everywhere.
You certainly should not be flying."

cqs.cq: If peanuts are so nutritious and filling, why is it that the people who eat them are the ones who get sick?
Do you have any evidence that peanuts are not a common allergen?
If peanuts were so nutritious, why are they causing so many deaths?
If the peanut allergy is not a real thing, why do peanuts have to be banned in schools and airplanes?

kateinhawaii_103.input:
kateinhawaii: "I personally have suffered from peanut allergies for over 40 years.
If there are packaged peanuts served on board a flight, it's 100% guaranteed that I will have a reaction from the peanut dust.
I do not agree with a buffer zone for a couple of reasons.
For me, it's the dust in the air.
Someone posted that the air circulates peanut dust right out of the air
but apparently not quick enough to prevent a life threatening reaction.
You know, airlines tried to create nonsmoking zones on airplanes but that didn't work either.
I have been on flights where nasty (and do I mean NASTY) flight attendants have made sarcastic remarks about me and my allergies especially on one Delta flight.
Northwest was great
because they respected their passengers enough to address their concerns
and prohibited peanuts altogether.
It was as much a relief to walk onto one of their flights as it was to walk onto one of the first smoke free flights!
Smokers use to use the same logic and reasoning to justify smoking on flights as these peanut proponents are using now.
I flew on many smoking flights and never needed to inject myself so that I could breathe
I can't say the same for flights with peanuts."

cqs.cq: Why would it be bad if peanuts were banned on flights?
Do you have any evidence to support your claim that peanuts have caused any harm to people with peanut allergies?
If peanuts are the issue, why not ban them from all flights as well as the peanut butter?
If peanuts are a problem, why not have a no peanuts policy for all flights?

lauraclare_136.input:
lauraclare: "I have two children with potentially life threatening allergies to peanuts.
Unlike what one person commented, this is not a latest illness fad.
The latest research indicates that peanut allergy doubled in children from 1997 to 2002 and that number continues to increase.
It is one of the most deadly food allergies.
The presence of nuts on planes is a real fear.
While my kids have other potentially deadly food allergies,
peanuts pose a unique risk.
Nuts break into fine pieces with dust that can become airborne.
Peanut butter is sticky and gets wiped on seats and tray tables.
Even the slightest microscopic amount of nuts can create an anaphylactic reaction.
Although EpiPens can help,
they are not 100% effective
and should not be considered a solution to the risk peanuts pose to allergic individuals on planes.
Additional steroids, Benadryl shots, oxygen and other medical intervention may be necessary to stop an anaphylactic reaction.
EpiPens may need to be administered every 15 to 30 minutes as well.
People still die even with intervention.
Please help protect people by offering people the opportunity to get peanut free flights or ban the sale and serving of nut products on the planes."

cqs.cq: Why is it a problem if peanuts are served on a plane if the flight attendants are trained to deal with allergic reactions?
If peanuts are banned on planes, then why not other foods that cause anaphylaxis as well?
If the airline is not responsible for what happens on the plane, why should they have to change their policies?
What if you were allergic to the peanuts but not the peanut butter?

mcliverty_188_1.input:
mcliverty: "Lack of space should be at the top of the list of issues the airlines need to address.
Whenever you hear about new airliners (the big 300) they don't mention improved arm and leg room.
I can handle the commuters because typically you aren't on there long, but cross country is killer in those economy class seats.
If they were ergonomically designed and comfortable, maybe they would be better, but they are terrible for lumbar and leg support.
You could probably save space by using more comfortable materials that are slimmer in design.
Even the same leg room with a 3" wider seat would be great.
Maybe a pop up foot rest/block from the floor to rest your feet on..
Air travel has really just become a necessary evil you have to survive.
It's certainly not something enjoyed or eagerly anticipated any longer."

cqs.cq: If you feel like flying is no longer a pleasure, why do you still fly?
Do you have any scientific evidence to support the claim that the airlines could make their seats more comfortable if they wanted to?
Why do you think it would be better if the airlines were making a profit off of their passengers rather than the government subsidizing their flights?
If you are looking for a more comfortable experience then why do you choose to fly economy class?

mcliverty_188_2.input:
mcliverty: "I avoid it if I can and consolidate my trips whenever possible.
I would rather drive 1012 hours in my car than fly at this point.
I travel with my dog about twice a year.
Because he is 28 pnds, he has to be checked and travel in cargo.
It costs anywhere from $300400 round trip to take him.
I would rather be allowed to put him in a carrier that is secured by the seat belt and have him travel in the seat next to me (that I purchase a ticket for), especially if I have to pay the same or more for his ticket in cargo as I do for mine.
The cost and stress of handing him over to cargo is wearing me down and I will most likely not take him on some future trips so they will loose my business.
If the airlines could make their processes more customer & dog friendly, it would make travel much more enjoyable.
I'm sure my dog would behave as well or better than some humans in the cabin."

cqs.cq: If you can afford to buy a ticket for yourself and your dog, why not just buy two separate tickets?
Do you have any evidence that dogs are more well behaved than people in the cabin?
If you see someone being rude or unruly on a flight, would you report them to the flight attendant?
So why not just take a train?

mfball__143.input:
mfball: "we listen to the top five Democrats
the Republicans had the top eleven or so in their debate
Chafee seemed like a trainwreck in the debate
O'Malley did alright
You might be right about his chances at getting the nomination
some candidates' chances could be influenced greatly by the amount of media coverage they're getting
People were swearing up and down that Bernie didn't have a shot
no one had ever heard of him
Hillary was the only one getting airtime
now he's getting a lot of attention
 he's a competitive candidate
 I don't know a lot about O'Malley
nobody's been talking about him or interviewing him
I don't think he came off as a "sideshow" candidate in the debate
If he started getting more attention, I imagine he could probably pull numbers at least as good as the lowest of the Republicans that are still being talked about"

cqs.cq: If that is the case, why do you think he is not getting more attention?
If the debate was the only thing that mattered, then why are you so concerned about the amount of media coverage that the candidates are getting?
If you consider Sanders to be a competitive candidate, then why do you think O'Malley is not a competitive candidate?
If he did a good job, why would we need to hear him talk about his plans and policy positions?

msrocker_127.input:
msrocker: "I agree with many others that even 3 hours is too long..
I think it should be 2
and should apply to all flights regardless of what airport, airline, destination, etc.
People are people no matter where they are
and should not be subjected to being miserable after paying a fee to fly somewhere!
Personally I have anxiety issues
and not being able to get out of an enclosed space is extremely stressful.
I think the airlines will now be forced to do all they can to prevent these delays.
Even though all will not be possible to prevent
I think there will be much less episodes wtih these new rules.
I think it goes a LONG ways to alleviate frustration
if we were informed in detail every 30 minutes.
I have been stranded on a plane 3 times
thankfully not more than 1 1/2 hours
but on one of these flights we were informed regularly along the way
and it made all the difference."

cqs.cq: If it is such a big issue for you, why do you keep flying?
Do you have any evidence that people are being left on a plane for over 2 hours and are being treated poorly?
If you have anxiety, would you rather fly for 2 hours or have to spend an extra 1 hour waiting for a flight that may not even be any better?
What if a plane is going to crash and there is no way to prevent it?

secretcurse__137.input:
secretcurse: "Don't hold your breath for the Green Party Presidential Debate on any of our major news networks
a person that wants to run on the Green Party (or any other party) ticket absolutely has that right and should be able to express their views in public
there's no obligation to give them equal time on privately owned networks compared to the Democratic or Republican candidates that actually have a shot at winning the election
Clinton is extremely likely to win the Democratic nomination
Sanders has a shot at beating her
O'Malley, Webb, and Chafee are all sideshow candidates in the primary
just like the nominees from the Green, Libertarian, and Communist parties will be in the general election
Everyone should be allowed to express themselves in public places freely, but a cable news network isn't a public place"

cqs.cq: Why should we allow cable news to be a private platform and not a public forum?
If a network wants to give a third party candidate airtime, why should they be forced to give the same amount of time to every third party candidate?
If a news network is not a public place, then why is it even considered news?
Why would a news network have the right to limit the amount of free speech they allow on their network?

secretcurse__139.input:
secretcurse: "The first debate was already limited to five people
According to the FEC
171 people have officially declared their candidacy for the Democratic Party nomination with the FEC (sort by party to see the 171 people a bit easier)
Do you think every single one of the 171 people that have filed the paperwork with the FEC declaring their candidacy deserves their fair shot at expressing themselves at the first debate"

cqs.cq: Do you think there is a point at which a person should not be allowed to run for office?
So why do you think that all of them should be included in the debates?
If so, why not just have a primary debate with 171 people in it?
Are you implying that the first debate should be a free for all where anyone can participate?

smg_72.input:
smg: "It has become abundantly clear that commercial airline travel is a "race to the bottom" that satisfies needs of neither passengers nor airline profits.
A change of environment, which can only be imposed from outside the industry is needed.
Imposition of common sense regulations,
would level the playing field and remove the impetus for airlines to costcut in this area.
The results would be better service to customers and a renormalization of the playing field from which the airlines compete without fear of being undercut.
This goes for most of the proposed new regulations.
I sincerely believe that these regulations are in the best interests of both airlines and passengers."

cqs.cq: Do you think that a regulation would make the airlines worse for the consumer?
Do you have any evidence to suggest that the airline industry is not already regulated enough?
Why would you not just let the free market decide what is best for the airlines and passengers?
If this is the case, why would you want to change it?

smr_174_1.input:
smr: "The problem of whether to deplane or not is a tricky one.
On one side is the fact that sitting for an excessive amount of time is uncomfortable at best and unhealthy at worst.
However, on the other side there will be considerable time lost with the deplaning and reboarding.
One item which should be addressed is food and drink.
If the airline would normally have food for the passengers on that flight it seems silly to deny access to anything more than a bag of peanuts and a glass of water.
This happened to my husband last week on a Delta flight from Newark to Amsterdam.
The passengers were sitting on the plane for over six hours, at the gate,
but they were only offered one bag of peanuts and a glass of water or orange juice.
The plane eventually took off at approximately 1 a.m.,
when it should have taken off at 6.40 the previous evening."

cqs.cq: If the flight was delayed by so much, why did they not just give the passengers a voucher for a meal at a restaurant?
Do you have a source that says flight delays are a result of pilots being hungry?
Why would it be a problem if they offered the passengers a bag of peanuts and a glass of water at the gate and then left them to sit on the plane for 6 hours?
If they are going to keep the plane waiting, why would they not just give the passengers a voucher for a free meal at the gate?

smr_174_2.input:
smr: "The dinner was not served until the normal point in the flight, somewhere over the Atlantic!
Allowing passengers off the plane into a holding area would not give them access to food and drink,
but would let them move around.
However, when passengers expect food to be served on a flight they will often depend on that being served
and an excessive delay in serving meals could be hazardous to some people's health,
especially when on a connecting flight
so there has been no opportunity to purchase food and drinks at the airport."

cqs.cq: If a passenger is in a life threatening situation, do they have to stay on the plane?
What if you were on a flight that was delayed to the point where the passengers would have been better off to just get off the plane and go to a hotel?
If so, why not just let people get up and get food if they need to eat?
So why do we serve food on planes at all if it is not safe to serve on the ground?

travellots_133_1.input:
travellots: "There should be no discrimination in how a passenger is bumped or compensated just because they may have paid less for a ticket or used frequent flyer miles.
Airline tickets are not lottery tickets.
One does not purchase a ticket hoping to reach a certain destination.
Same as if one pays $4 for a cup of coffee or $1, the cup is supposed to have coffee in it.
The price does not dictate that "maybe" you will get the product or service.
Also, the airline decides what prices or miles are used to purchase a promise to get you from point A to point B.
If they can not afford to give  a ticket for that price, they should not sell it.
When you reserve a ticket, the assumption is that you will be taken from point A to point B by the times given by the airline.
A passenger does not purchase a ticket just to see if maybe they can get somewhere because they have nothing better to do."

cqs.cq: So what if the airline has a flight that has a lot of empty seats?
Do you have any evidence to suggest that airlines are lying about the chances of being bumped?
If you buy a ticket for a flight and the airline cancels the flight, why are you entitled to compensation for the cancellation?
Why should the airline be forced to give you a seat on a flight if it is not necessary to fulfill the airline's obligation to transport you to your destination?

travellots_133_2.input:
travellots: "If compensation is not high enough, the airlines will not have an incentive to schedule properly.
It is not fair to allow airlines to discriminate against lower fared passengers or "free" passengers
since it is the airline, not the passenger or government, who gave that passenger a seat.
Otherwise, airlines can advertise low fares or con you into using them to build up your "miles" and then always bump you for someone who paid more.
In away,it is the same as being able to increase your ticket price anytime after purchase.
When you are bumped, there are a lot of hidden extra costs
It irks me that airlines seem to be treating passengers more and more as if they have nothing better to do but wait around in airports and not get to where the airline promised to bring them.
Again, the airline sets the agreed price or miles for a seat, no one else.
The incentives to the airline should be to get all confirmed passengers (regardless of price paid) to the destination promised."

cqs.cq: Why would the airline want to fill the plane if they can make more money by selling seats to higher fare paying passengers?
Do you have any evidence that airlines are bumping people who have paid a lower price in favor of people who have paid a higher price?
Why do you think airlines have the right to dictate what kind of compensation they give to passengers if they are bumped?
What if the airline had the option to offer you a flight on a different day or at a later time for the same price?

zuclinator_125.input:
zuclinator: "I know Delta serves peanuts
as I travel to and from Detroit on Delta.
I was really surprised to learn this
as I didn't know until I was on the plane and in the air.
shouldn't they tell people before they pay for a flight?
Oh and the two row minimum around a person with a peanut allergy is a joke.
Someone with a peanut allergy is not going to be protected by that!"

cqs.cq: Why do you care if peanuts are served on a flight if you are not allergic to them?
Would you have the airline put a peanut allergy warning on the ticket before you buy it?
If you have a peanut allergy, why would you want to fly on a plane that serves peanuts?
If a person is allergic to peanuts, then why would they go on a plane that serves peanuts?

TRUMP_114_1.input:
TRUMP: "we have been told through investigative reporting that he owes about $ 650 million to Wall Street and foreign banks
You learn a lot from financial disclosure
That I can tell you
you should go down and take a look at that
I 'm extremely underleveraged
The report that said $ 650
a lot of friends of mine that know my business
It 's not a lot of money relative to what I had
The buildings that were in question , they said in the same report , which was—actually , it was n't even a bad story , to be honest with you , but the buildings are worth $ 3.9 billion
the $ 650 is n't even on that
it 's not $ 650
It 's much less than that
I could give you a list of banks
I would—if that would help you , I would give you a list of banks
These are very fine institutions
very fine banks
I could do that very quickly
I am very underleveraged
I have a great company
I have a tremendous income
the reason I say that is not in a braggadocios way
It 's because it 's about time that this country had somebody running it that has an idea about money
we have $ 20 trillion in debt"

cqs.cq: If he is so underleveraged, why does he have to declare bankruptcy so often?
Are you saying that Trump is the first president who has an idea about money?
Why would you say that if you are in debt and struggling to pay it back you have no idea about money?
If you can prove that he is not worth billions of dollars, then why not do it?

TRUMP_114_2.input:
TRUMP: "our country 's a mess
it 's one thing to have $ 20 trillion in debt
Our airports are like from a third world country
You land at LaGuardia , you land at Kennedy , you land at LAX , you land at Newark , and you come in from Dubai and Qatar and you see these incredible—you come in from China , you see these incredible airports
we 've become a third world country
our bridges are good
everything 's in great shape
our airports
the worst of all things has happened
We owe $ 20 trillion
we 're a mess
We have n't even started
we 've spent $ 6 trillion in the Middle East
according to a report that I just saw
Whether it 's 6 or 5
 it looks like it 's 6
we could have rebuilt our country twice
it 's really a shame
it 's politicians like Secretary Clinton that have caused this problem
Our country has tremendous problems
We 're a debtor nation
We 're a serious debtor nation
we have a country that needs new roads , new tunnels , new bridges , new airports , new schools , new hospitals
we don't have the money
it 's been squandered on so many of your ideas"

cqs.cq: What if the money they are spending on airports and roads is actually making the country more efficient and productive and increasing the standard of living?
Do you have any evidence that the Obama administration has spent more money on infrastructure than the Trump administration?
So why are you voting for him again if he has done nothing to change your mind?
And what do you plan to do to fix the problems you see in America?

TRUMP_121_1.input:
TRUMP: "I do think it's time
it's all words
it's all sound bites
I built an unbelievable company
Some of the greatest assets anywhere in the world
real estate assets anywhere in the world
beyond the United States, in Europe, lots of different places
It's an unbelievable company
on occasion, four times, we used certain laws that are there
when Secretary Clinton talks about people that didn't get paid, first of all, they did get paid a lot, but taken advantage of the laws of the nation
if you want to change the laws, you've been there a long time, change the laws
you've been there a long time,
I take advantage of the laws of the nation
I'm running a company
My obligation right now is to do well for myself, my family, my employees, for my companies
that's what I do
what she doesn't say is that tens of thousands of people that are unbelievably happy and that love me"

cqs.cq: So what if someone has a bad experience with you or your company and they are not happy with you?
Do you have any evidence that Trump is right that tens of thousands of people love him?
So why is it bad to use the law to get a benefit?
Are you implying that the people that are not happy are not good people?

TRUMP_121_2.input:
TRUMP: "I'll give you an example
We're just opening up on Pennsylvania Avenue right next to the White House
if I don't get there one way, I'm going to get to Pennsylvania Avenue another
we're opening the Old Post Office
I'm a year ahead of schedule
that's what this country should be doing
We build roads
they cost two and three and four times what they're supposed to cost
We buy products for our military
they come in at costs that are so far above what they were supposed to be
we don't have people that know what they're doing
When we look at the budget, the budget is bad to a large extent
we have people that have no idea as to what to do and how to buy
The Trump International is way under budget
way ahead of schedule
we should be able to do that for our country"

cqs.cq: Why is the Trump International such a good example of the US government?
Do you have any evidence to suggest that the Trump Organization can handle a project of this magnitude?
Why would you build a hotel to build a hotel?
If you have a better idea of how to build a hotel and you can do it cheaper and faster, why would you want to build a hotel?

TRUMP_125_1.input:
TRUMP: "Secretary Clinton doesn't want to use a couple of words, and that's law and order
If we don't have it, we're not going to have a country
when I look at what's going on in Charlotte, a city I love, a city where I have investments, when I look at what's going on throughout various parts of our country, whether it's—I mean, I can just keep naming them all day long
I just got today the, as you know, the endorsement of the Fraternal Order of Police, we just—just came in
We have endorsements from, I think, almost every police group, very—I mean, a large percentage of them in the United States
We have a situation where we have our inner cities, African- Americans, Hispanics are living in hell
it's so dangerous
You walk down the street, you get shot
In Chicago, they've had thousands of shootings, thousands since January 1st
I'm saying, where is this
Is this a war-torn country
What are we doing
we have to stop the violence
In a place like Chicago, where thousands of people have been killed, thousands over the last number of years
almost 4,000 have been killed since Barack Obama became president"

cqs.cq: If so, then why does he keep making it sound like he is going to make things worse for the people of Chicago?
Do you have any evidence to support your claim that Chicago has a higher rate of murder than El Salvador?
If we want to make the inner cities safer, why not make them into a separate country?
If the police are being so bad, why are they the ones who have the power to make the change?

TRUMP_125_2.input:
TRUMP: "almost 4,000 people in Chicago have been killed
 whether or not in a place like Chicago you do stop and frisk, which worked very well, Mayor Giuliani is here, worked very well in New York
It brought the crime rate way down
you take the gun away from criminals that shouldn't be having it
We have gangs roaming the street
in many cases, they're illegally here, illegal immigrants
they have guns
they shoot people
we have to be very strong
we have to be very vigilant
We have to be—we have to know what we're doing
 our police, in many cases, are afraid to do anything
We have to protect our inner cities
African-American communities are being decimated by crime, decimated
No"

cqs.cq: If you are a police officer, why would you need to have a gun?
Do you have a source that shows that the police in Chicago are afraid to do anything?
If so, why are you not making the same argument about black crime?
If you see the police as the problem, why do you want to make them more powerful?

TRUMP_127.input:
TRUMP: "you're wrong
It went before a judge, who was a very against-police judge
It was taken away from her
our mayor, our new mayor, refused to go forward with the case
They would have won an appeal
If you look at it, throughout the country, there are many places where it's allowed"

cqs.cq: What happens if the police department refuses to give the dashcam footage to the public and to the defense?
What is your source for the claim that the police did nothing wrong?
If so, why did the police not just let her go?
What is the point of having laws if you are just going to ignore them?

TRUMP_129.input:
TRUMP: "the argument is that we have to take the guns away from these people that have them
they are bad people that shouldn't have them
These are felons
These are people that are bad people that shouldn't be
when you have 3,000 shootings in Chicago from January 1st
when you have 4,000 people killed in Chicago by guns, from the beginning of the presidency of Barack Obama, his hometown
you have to have stop-and-frisk
You need more police
You need a better community
relation
You don't have good community relations in Chicago
It's terrible
I have property there
It's terrible what's going on in Chicago
when you look—and Chicago's not the only
you go to Ferguson
you go to so many different places
You need better relationships
I agree with Secretary Clinton on this
You need better relationships between the communities and the police
in some cases, it's not good
you look at Dallas, where the relationships were really studied
the relationships were really a beautiful thing
then five police officers were killed one night very violently
there's some bad things going on
Some really bad things
we need—Lester, we need law and order
we need law and order in the inner cities
the people that are most affected by what's happening are African-American and Hispanic people
it's very unfair to them what our politicians are allowing to happen"

cqs.cq: So if we are going to do nothing to stop the bad people, then why do we need to have guns to protect ourselves from the bad people?
Do you have any evidence to back up your claim that inner city communities are disproportionately affected by crime?
If that is the case, why are they making gun laws that will disproportionately affect those communities?
If we are going to take away guns, then why do we need to build a wall to keep people from coming in?

TRUMP_13.input:
TRUMP: "Secretary Clinton and others , politicians , should have been doing this for years , not right now
we 've created a movement
They should have been doing this for years
What 's happened to our jobs and our country and our economy generally is—look , we owe $ 20 trillion
We can not do it any longer , Lester"

cqs.cq: If the US can afford to borrow $20 trillion and pay the interest, then why is it a problem?
Do you have any evidence that this is true?
If the debt was caused by the wealthy and the government, why are they the ones that have to pay it back?
If we can not pay the debt, why should we be worried about what happens if we default?

TRUMP_140_1.input:
TRUMP: "a lot of people even within my own party want to give certain rights to people on watch lists and no- fly lists
I agree with you
When a person is on a watch list or a no-fly list
 These are very, very good people
they're protecting the Second Amendment
I have the endorsement of the NRA
I'm very proud of
we have to look very strongly at no-fly lists and watch lists
when people are on there, even if they shouldn't be on there, we'll help them, we'll help them legally, we'll help them get off
I tend to agree with that quite strongly
you were the one that brought up the words super-predator about young black youth
that's a term that I think was a—it's—it's been horribly met
you've apologized for it"

cqs.cq: Why do you keep saying that you agree with him when you do not?
Do you have any evidence to back up the claim that there are a lot of people in your own party who want to give certain rights to people on watch lists and no-fly lists?
So why are you calling him a racist if he apologized for his past racist comments?
If you have evidence that these people are not a threat, then why do you want to keep them on a watch list?

TRUMP_140_2.input:
TRUMP: "it was a terrible thing to say
when it comes to stop-and-frisk, you know, you're talking about takes guns away
I'm talking about taking guns away from gangs and people that use them
I really don't think you disagree with me on this
maybe there's a political reason why you can't say it
in New York City, stop-and-frisk, we had 2,200 murders, and stop-and-frisk brought it down to 500 murders
Five hundred murders is a lot of murders
It's hard to believe, 500 is like supposed to be good
 we went from 2,200 to 500
 it was continued on by Mayor Bloomberg
it was terminated by current mayor
stop-and- frisk had a tremendous impact on the safety of New York City
Tremendous beyond belief"

cqs.cq: If stop and frisk is so good at stopping crime, why are there so many guns on the streets?
If you are a politician, why should people trust you on this issue when you have such a poor track record on it?
If stop and frisk was so effective, why did it have to be stopped?
Why would you want to stop the police from stopping a known murderer if it means they might get to kill more people?

TRUMP_166.input:
TRUMP: "nobody was pressing it , nobody was caring much about it
I figured you 'd ask the question tonight , of course
nobody was caring much about it
I was the one that got him to produce the birth certificate
I did a good job
Secretary Clinton also fought it
now , everybody in mainstream is going to say , oh , that 's not true
Look , it 's true
Sidney Blumenthal sent a reporter
you just have to take a look at CNN , the last week , the interview with your former campaign manager
she was involved
just like she ca n't bring back jobs , she ca n't produce"

cqs.cq: If so, do you see how that is different from the Trump example you used?
Do you have any evidence that she was involved in the birth certificate issue?
If the goal is to make Hillary look bad, why would Trump bring up the birth certificate at all?
If you are going to make the case that she is a liar and is unfit to be President, why not do it in a way that is not so easily debunked as false?

TRUMP_170.input:
TRUMP: "I say nothing
I was able to get him to produce it
He should have produced it a long time before
When you talk about healing , I think that I 've developed very , very good relationships over the last little while with the African-American community
you can see that
I feel that they really wanted me to come to that conclusion
I did a great job and a great service not only for the country , but even for the president , in getting him to produce his birth certificate"

cqs.cq: If he was a good president, why did he hide his birth certificate?
Do you have any evidence that Obama has ever lied about his birth certificate?
If the President of the United States is required to show his birth certificate to the public, why would he not be required to show it to the Congress?
If he did such a great job making peace, why do we need sanctions to pressure North Korea into stopping its violent threats?

TRUMP_174_2.input:
TRUMP: "I also notice the very nasty commercials that you do on me in so many different ways , which I do n't do on you
Maybe I 'm trying to save the money
is n't that amazing
I settled that lawsuit with no admission of guilt , but that was a lawsuit brought against many real estate firms , and it 's just one of those things
I 'll go one step further
In Palm Beach , Florida , tough community , a brilliant community , a wealthy community , probably the wealthiest community there is in the world , I opened a club , and really got great credit for it
No discrimination against African- Americans, against Muslims, against anybody
it's a tremendously successful club
I'm so glad I did it
 I have been given great credit for what I did
'm very, very proud of it
that's the way I feel
That is the true way I feel"

cqs.cq: If you have so much respect for the LGBTQ community, why did you try to ban them from your club?
So why is it that you have to say it so much if you really believe it?
But why is it that the club had a rule that you had to be white to get in?
If you are so proud of your accomplishments, why do you need to keep talking about them?

TRUMP_183.input:
TRUMP: "I do want to say that I was just endorsed
and more are coming next week
it will be over 200 admirals
many of them here—admirals and generals endorsed me to lead this country
That just happened
many more are coming
I was just endorsed by ICE
They 've never endorsed anybody before on immigration
I was just recently endorsed—16,500 Border Patrol agents
when Secretary Clinton talks about this , I mean , I 'll take the admirals and I 'll take the generals any day over the political hacks that I see that have led our country so brilliantly over the last 10 years with their knowledge
look at the mess that we 're in
As far as the cyber , I agree to parts of what Secretary Clinton said
We should be better than anybody else
perhaps we 're not
I do n't think anybody knows it was Russia that broke into the DNC"

cqs.cq: Why would the Russians want to do that?
Why would you say that if you don't think Russia did it?
If the Russians were the ones who broke into the DNC, why would they put up a fake website that was meant to look like it belonged to the RNC?
So what if it was Russia?

TRUMP_192.input:
TRUMP: "President Obama and Secretary Clinton created a vacuum the way they got out of Iraq
they got out—what , they should n't have been in
once they got in , the way they got out was a disaster
ISIS was formed
she talks about taking them out
She 's been doing it a long time
She 's been trying to take them out for a long time
they would n't have even been formed if they left some troops behind , like 10,000 or maybe something more than that
then you would n't have had them
as I 've been saying for a long time
I think you 'll agree
I said it to you once
had we taken the oil—and we should have taken the oil—ISIS would not have been able to form either
we should have taken the oil
the oil was their primary source of income
now they have the oil all over the place
including the oil—a lot of the oil in Libya
was another one of her disasters"

cqs.cq: If the oil was the main source of income for ISIS, why do you think they would have had the money to build up their army and infrastructure if they were only taking the oil from Iraq?
Where is your evidence that ISIS was formed because Obama and Hillary didn't leave troops in Iraq?
If taking the oil would have prevented ISIS, why did ISIS not form in Saudi Arabia where the oil is?
If you have the military to take the oil, why would you leave it in the hands of the people that are killing the people that you are supposed to be protecting?

TRUMP_202_1.input:
TRUMP: "The secretary said very strongly about working with—we've been working with them for many years, and we have the greatest mess anyone's ever seen
You look at the Middle East, it's a total mess
Under your direction, to a large extent
you look at the Middle East, you started the Iran deal, that's another beauty where you have a country that was ready to fall, I mean, they were doing so badly
They were choking on the sanctions
now they're going to be actually probably a major power at some point pretty soon, the way they're going
when you look at NATO
I was asked on a major show, what do you think of NATO
you have to understand, I'm a businessperson
I did really well
I have common sense. And I said, well, I'll tell you. I haven't given lots of thought to NATO. But two things
the 28 countries of NATO, many of them aren't paying their fair share"

cqs.cq: If they are not paying their fair share, why do you want to keep them in NATO?
So you think that the US is being taken advantage of by the other NATO countries?
If you see the US as the most powerful country in the world, why would you want to get rid of it?
If you think NATO is so bad, why do you want to keep it?

TRUMP_202_2.input:
TRUMP: "that bothers me
we should be asking—we're defending them, and they should at least be paying us what they're supposed to be paying by treaty and contract
NATO could be obsolete
I was very strong on this, and it was actually covered very accurately in the New York Times, which is unusual for the New York Times, to be honest—but I said, they do not focus on terror
 I was very strong. And I said it numerous times
about four months ago, I read on the front page of the Wall Street Journal that NATO is opening up a major terror division
that's great. And I think we should get
we pay approximately 73 percent of the cost of NATO
It's a lot of money to protect other people. But I'm all for NATO. But I said they have to focus on terror, also
they're going to do that
 I'm not going to get credit for it—but that was largely because of what I was saying and my criticism of NATO
we have to get NATO to go into the Middle East with us, in addition to surrounding nations, and we have to knock the hell out of ISIS, and we have to do it fast
when ISIS formed in this vacuum created by Barack Obama and Secretary Clinton. And believe me, you were the ones that took out the troops. Not only that, you named the day. They couldn't believe it. They sat back probably and said, I can't believe it"

cqs.cq: If so, why would that make a difference in the case of ISIS?
Where do you get the information that ISIS formed as a result of Obama and Clinton?
If the US is paying 73% of the cost, why does it matter if NATO is not focused on terror?
What if you just want to go back to the pre 9/11 world?

TRUMP_222.input:
TRUMP: "I have much better judgment than she does
There 's no question about that
I also have a much better temperament than she has
she spent hundreds of millions of dollars on an advertising
they get Madison Avenue into a room
they put names
temperament , let 's go after
my strongest asset , maybe by far , is my temperament
I have a winning temperament
I know how to win
She does not have a
Wrong
there 's a person with a temperament that 's got a problem
The AFL-CIO the other day , behind the blue screen , I do n't know who you were talking to , Secretary Clinton , but you were totally out of control
 I do n't know who you were talking to"

cqs.cq: If you think that Trump is out of control, why do you want to vote for him?
So what does that mean in terms of policy?
So what if a man said the same thing?
Do you see the President as a CEO or as a leader of a nation?

TRUMP_236.input:
TRUMP: "It 's not an accurate one at all
It 's not an accurate one
I just want to give a lot of things
just to respond
I agree with her on one thing
The single greatest problem the world has is nuclear armament , nuclear weapons
not global warming
like you think
your—your president thinks
Nuclear is the single greatest threat
Just to go down the list , we defend Japan , we defend Germany , we defend South Korea , we defend Saudi Arabia , we defend countries
They do not pay us
they should be paying us
we are providing tremendous service
we 're losing a fortune
we 're losing
we lose on everything
All I said , that it 's very possible that if they do n't pay a fair share
this is n't 40 years ago where we could do what we 're doing
if they do n't pay a fair share
We ca n't defend Japan , a behemoth , selling us cars by the million"

cqs.cq: If you think we should be making more money, why do you think the Japanese should be paying us for defense?
Are you saying that the only reason we are keeping Japan safe is because we get to sell them cars?
If they are so bad at selling cars, why are they selling us so many?
If they are not paying, why should they get the same level of protection as us?

TRUMP_240_1.input:
TRUMP: "for what Secretary Clinton was saying about nuclear with Russia , she 's very cavalier in the way she talks about various countries
Russia has been expanding their
they have a much newer capability than we do
We have not been updating from the new standpoint
I looked the other night
I was seeing B-52s
they 're old enough that your father , your grandfather could be flying them
we are not keeping up with other countries
 I would like everybody to end it
just get rid of it
I would certainly not do first strike
once the nuclear alternative happens , it 's over
At the same time , we have to be prepared
I ca n't take anything off the table
you look at some of these countries , you look at North Korea , we 're doing nothing there
China should solve that problem for us
China should go into North Korea
China is totally powerful as it relates to North Korea"

cqs.cq: If the Chinese are not going to stop them, then why should the US?
If China is so powerful and capable of solving the North Korea problem, why has it not done so yet?
Why would China do anything to help the US?
If China was able to take care of North Korea then why would they do it?

CL_8.input:
CL: "Doesn’t it worry you at all that you're taking advantage of people when they are really in no position to negotiate?
They have absolutely very little choice except to take the terms that are being offered to them"

cqs.cq: If they do have a choice, then why are they taking the deal you are offering?
Do you have evidence that most people do not have a choice in their relationship?
So if the employer is taking advantage of someone, why is that person not a victim?
Is it really taking advantage of them if they are getting a better deal than they would have gotten otherwise?

MT_14.input:
MT: "We have indeed required those products to have very large warnings on them, telling people about their salt and fat content
And we don’t allow them to say things which are misleading
We don’t allow fatty products to say they're healthy
I've got in front of me a letter from a credit card company
There are two figures on this letter which really stand out: 0% per annum new balance transfers, 0% per annum new money transfers
Now, underneath that, in small print, it becomes absolutely clear that you’ll be paying all sorts of charges
And then very, very quickly you’ll be lured into paying a very large charge
Do you think it’s responsible to encourage people to mis-read something like that?
I’ve got all the information there in front of me
Why is that irresponsible?"

cqs.cq: If we are so concerned about people making bad decisions with their money, why do we allow them to vote in elections?
Do you really believe that the average person will read the fine print and understand the charges?
Why would you call it irresponsible if the company is being honest about the charges and the customer is aware of the charges?
Why is it irresponsible to encourage people to read the fine print?

MT_45.input:
MT: "Claire’s absolutely right about that
But then the problem is that that form of capitalism wasn’t generating sufficient surpluses
And so therefore where did the money flow
It didn’t flow into those industrial activities
 because in the developed world that wasn’t making enough money"

cqs.cq: If the money is being generated by the finance sector, why are they not investing in these sectors?
So why did they need to create a global economic system to get that money to flow into those areas if they could have just taxed the rich people and given it to the poor people?
If the problem was that the developed world wasn’t making enough money, why did it matter if the money went to the wealthy or the working class?
So why would you want to keep the capitalist system if it was so bad?

ND_23.input:
ND: " I think in the current situation that both savers and borrowers, if you're talking about individual people, are doing extremely badly
many people are unable to make ends meet and are having to take debt out at huge levels of interest
On the other hand, savers are earning nothing in interest
And what this needs is not simply us putting moral blame on one side or the other
but actually putting moral blame on a set of economic policies and political decisions that have led to credit liberalisation."

cqs.cq: If so, why do you think this is a problem?
Can you show me any evidence of the credit liberalisation you are talking about?
If the economic policies and political decisions are the problem, then why not try to change them?

If it is a moral failing to encourage people to borrow money to buy things they can not afford, then is it not also a moral failing to make it so difficult to save money that people are forced to borrow money in order to survive?

CF_62.input:
CF: "RS: Provide that for our young people
 These are young adults; you’re kind of treating them as though they’re passive recipients of something.
 And I suppose that’s my concern; how do we encourage the young?
It’s not beyond the imagination to imagine the young might get up and go and do something about this, other than kind of sit and wait to be handed something.
Now you’re saying “Provide that for our young people”, and in a way that’s where I’m going."

cqs.cq: Why are you making the assumption that the government is the only one that can provide for the young people?
Why would you want to give them a way to change the world if you believe it is going to be a bad thing?
So why do you want to make it so that young people do not have to go to college to get a good job?
Why would we want to make our young people more angry?

JW_35.input:
JW: "JW has got a rather nuanced view, that the way they're mis-used can have morally damaging consequences
Well, debt is morally neutral in the sense that it can be good to be in debt
 Sometimes it’s a good idea, and sometimes it’s a bad idea
And so I think there’s been broad agreement about that in the discussion so far
The question is why is there too much debt?
 Why are people taking on too much debt?
 this one is the elaboration of the previous question Now,
a lot of people come up with rather glib moral answers: somehow bankers want them to get into excessive debt
 which is a very peculiar idea, when you think that it’s the bankers who aren’t going to get repaid. So it’s a very odd idea
there’s too much debt for the same reason that there are too many unmarried mothers, and for the same reason that you get an overproduction of sheep."

cqs.cq: What if the reason why there are too many unmarried mothers is because of the same factors that cause there to be too much debt?
Why do you think there are too many unmarried mothers?
If a sheep farmer raises too many sheep and there is a glut of sheep, does that mean the farmer is morally wrong for raising too many sheep?
What makes the fact that people are making choices that cause harm to themselves and others a bad thing?

CLINTON_1_1.input:
CLINTON: "The central question in this election is really what kind of country we want to be and what kind of future we 'll build together
Today is my granddaughter 's second birthday
I think about this a lot
we have to build an economy that works for everyone , not just those at the top
we need new jobs , good jobs , with rising incomes
I want us to invest in you
I want us to invest in your future
jobs in infrastructure , in advanced manufacturing , innovation and technology , clean , renewable energy , and small business
most of the new jobs will come from small business
We also have to make the economy fairer
That starts with raising the national minimum wage and also guarantee , finally , equal pay for women 's work
I also want to see more companies do profit-sharing"

cqs.cq: If so, what makes you think they would be willing to do that?
Do you have any evidence to suggest that making companies do profit sharing will actually increase the minimum wage?
If so, why not just make it a national standard to pay all workers a living wage?
If you say that the economy is unfair then what do you mean by unfair?

TRUMP_99.input:
TRUMP: "I will release them as soon as the audit
I 've been under audit almost for 15 years
I know a lot of wealthy people that have never been audited
I said , do you get audited
do you get audited
I get audited almost every year
in a way , I should be complaining
I 'm not even complaining
I do n't mind it
It 's almost become a way of life
I get audited by the IRS
But other people don't
We have a situation in this country that has to be taken care of
I will release my tax returns—against my lawyer 's wishes—when she releases her 33,000 e-mails that have been deleted
As soon as she releases them , I will release
I will release my tax returns
that 's against—my lawyers
they say , `` Do n't do it . '' I will tell you this
No—in fact , watching shows , they 're reading the papers
Almost every lawyer says , you do n't release your returns until the audit 's complete
When the audit 's complete , I 'll do it
I would go against them if she releases her e-mails"

cqs.cq: So if you have nothing to hide, why are you fighting to keep them secret?
Do you have any evidence that the IRS is not doing their job and that Trump is being audited as a form of harassment?
So if she released the emails, would that mean he would have to release his tax returns?
If Trump is not worried about the audit, why does he care if Hillary releases her emails?

TRUMP_174_1.input:
TRUMP: "I would love to respond
I got to watch in preparing for this some of your debates against Barack Obama
You treated him with terrible disrespect
I watched the way you talk now about how lovely everything is and how wonderful you are
It does n't work that way
You were after him
you were trying to—you even sent out or your campaign sent out pictures of him in a certain garb , very famous pictures
I do n't think you can deny that
just last week , your campaign manager said it was true
when you tried to act holier than thou , it really does n't work
as far as the lawsuit , yes , when I was very young , I went into my father 's company , had a real estate company in Brooklyn and Queens , and we , along with many , many other companies throughout the country—it was a federal lawsuit—were sued
We settled the suit with zero—with no admission of guilt
It was very easy to do
I notice you bring that up a lot"

cqs.cq: If you were so innocent, why did you settle the lawsuit?
Do you have any evidence to suggest that Trump was sued for fraud?
If you have no evidence that Obama did anything wrong, why do you keep bringing it up?
If Trump is so sure he is innocent, then why does he keep lying about it?

TRUMP_112.input:
TRUMP: "That was more than a mistake
That was done purposely
That was not a mistake
When you have your staff taking the Fifth Amendment , taking the Fifth so they 're not prosecuted
when you have the man that set up the illegal server taking the Fifth
it 's disgraceful
this country thinks it's—really thinks it 's disgraceful , also
As far as my tax returns , you do n't learn that much from tax returns"

cqs.cq: If so, what is the point of the tax returns if they do not show anything that can be used to discredit you?
Do you have a source that says that the tax returns will show Trump is guilty of anything?
Why would you need to make up something if your tax returns were not being used for political purposes?
Do you really think people care about your tax returns?

CLINTON_244_1.input:
CLINTON: "let me start by saying , words matter
they really matter when you are president
Words matter when you run for president
I want to reassure our allies in Japan and South Korea and elsewhere that we have mutual defense treaties and we will honor them
It is essential that America 's word be good
I know that this campaign has caused some questioning and worries on the part of many leaders across the globe
I 've talked with a number of them
I want to—on behalf of myself , and I think on behalf of a majority of the American people , say that , you know , our word is good
It 's also important that we look at the entire global situation
There 's no doubt that we have other problems with Iran
personally , I 'd rather deal with the other problems having put that lid on their nuclear program than still to be facing that
Donald never tells you what he would do
Would he have started a war ?
Would he have bombed Iran ?"

cqs.cq: If the US was going to bomb Iran, why would he tell us that?
Why would he want to bomb Iran if he knew that would cause a war?
So why would he not have bombed Iran if he was in a position to do so?
If you are so concerned about Iran, why not bomb them?
